{{Infobox language | name = Bench | nativename = ''Bencnon'' | pronunciation = {{IPA|bentʂnon}} | states = [[Ethiopia]] | region = [[Bench Maji Zone]], [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples Region|SNNPR]] | speakers = 348,000 Bench Non, 8,000 Mer, 490 She | date = 2007 | ref = e18 | familycolor = Afro-Asiatic | fam2 = [[Omotic languages|Omotic]] | fam3 = [[North Omotic languages|North]] | dia1 = Benc Non (Benesho) | dia2 = Mer (Mieru) | dia3 = She (Kaba) | iso3 = bcq | lingua = 16-BBA-a | notice = IPA | glotto = benc1235 | glottorefname = Bench }} '''Bench''' (''Bencnon'', '''Shenon''' or '''Mernon''', formerly called '''Gimira''' Rapold 2006) is a Northern [[Omotic languages|Omotic]] language of the "Gimojan" subgroup, spoken by about 174,000 people (in 1998) in the [[Bench Maji Zone]] of the [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples Region]], in southern [[Ethiopia]], around the towns of [[Mizan Teferi]] and [[Shewa Gimira]]. It has three varieties: Benchnon, Shenon, and Mernon, which Blench (2006) considers to be distinct languages but which Rapold (2006) states are "...mutually intelligible...varieties of one and the same language". In unusual variance from most of the other languages in Africa, Bench has [[retroflex consonant]] phonemes.Breeze 1988. The language is also noteworthy in that it has six [[phonemic tone]]s, one of only a handful of languages in the world that have this many.Wedekind 1983, 1985a, 1985b. Bench has a [[Whistled language|whistled form]] used primarily by male speakers, which permits communication over greater distances than spoken Bench. The whistle can be created using the lips or made from a hollow created with both hands. Additionally, this form of the language may be communicated via the 5-stringed [[krar]].Wedekind 1983 ==Phonology== The phonemic [[vowel]]s of Bench are {{IPA|/i e a o u/}}. There are six phonemic [[tone (linguistics)|tone]]s: five level tones (numbered 1 to 5 in the literature, with 1 being the lowest) and one rising tone 23 {{IPA|/˨˧/}}. The top tone is sometimes realized as a high rising 45 {{IPA|[˦˥]}}.Note that this is the East Asian tone numbering convention, and the opposite of the literature for other African languages, where 1 is high and 5 is low. The issue will be avoided here by using [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] diacritics. On the vowel ''o,'' they are {{IPA|/ő ó ō ò ȍ ǒ/}} The consonants are: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | ! [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! [[Coronal consonant|Coronal]] ! [[Palatoalveolar consonant|Palato-
alveolar]] ! [[Retroflex consonant|Retroflex]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! colspan="2" | [[Nasal stop|Nasal]] | align="center"| {{IPA|m}} | align="center"| {{IPA|n}} | | | | |- ! rowspan="3" |[[Plosive consonant|Plosive]] ! [[Voiceless consonant|Voiceless]] | align="center"| {{IPA|p}} | align="center"| {{IPA|t}} | | | align="center"| {{IPA|k}} | align="center"| {{IPA|ʔ}} |- ! [[Voiced consonant|Voiced]] | align="center"| {{IPA|b}} | align="center"| {{IPA|d}} | | | align="center"|{{IPA|ɡ}} | |- ! [[Ejective]] | align="center"| {{IPA|pʼ}} | align="center"| {{IPA|tʼ}} | | | align="center"| {{IPA|kʼ}} | |- ! rowspan="2"|[[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] ! Voiceless | | align="center"| {{IPA|ts}} | align="center"| {{IPA|tʃ}} | align="center"| {{IPA|tʂ}} | | |- ! Ejective | | align="center"| {{IPA|tsʼ}} | align="center"| {{IPA|tʃʼ}} | align="center"| {{IPA|tʂʼ}} | | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ! Voiceless | | align="center"| {{IPA|s}} | align="center"| {{IPA|ʃ}} | align="center"| {{IPA|ʂ}} | | align="center"| {{IPA|h}} |- ! Voiced | | align="center"| {{IPA|z}} | align="center"| {{IPA|ʒ}} | align="center"| {{IPA|ʐ}} | | |- ! colspan="2"| [[Rhotic consonant|Rhotic]] | | align="center"| {{IPA|r}} | | | | |- ! colspan="2" | [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | align="center"| {{IPA|l}} | align="center"| {{IPA|j}} | | | |} All of these can occur [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized]], but only before {{IPA|/a/}}, suggesting an alternate analysis of a sixth phonemic vowel {{IPA|/ja/}}. Labialized consonants are reported for {{IPA|[p, b, s, ɡ,]}} and {{IPA|[ʔ]}}, but their phonemic status is unclear; they only occur after {{IPA|/i/}}. For the phoneme {{IPA|/p/}} the realizations of {{IPA|[pʰ]}} and [f] are in free variation; {{IPA|/j/}} has the allophone {{IPA|[w]}} before back vowels. The syllable structure is (C)V(C)(C)(C) + tone or (C) N (C), where C represents any consonant, V any vowel, N any nasal, and brackets an optional element. CC clusters consist of a [[continuant]] followed by a [[plosive]], [[fricative]], or [[affricate]]; in CCC clusters, the first consonant must be one of {{IPA|/r/ /j/ /m/ /p/}} or {{IPA|/pʼ/}}, the second either {{IPA|/n/}} or a voiceless fricative, and the third {{IPA|/t/}} or {{IPA|/k/}}. ==Grammar== ===Nouns=== Plurals may optionally be formed by adding the suffix {{IPA|[-n̄d]}}; however, these are rarely used except with definite nouns. E.g.: {{IPA|[wű īŋɡn̄d]}} "her relatives"; {{IPA|[ātsn̄dī bá ka̋ŋɡ]}} "all the people". ===Pronouns=== ====Personal pronouns==== {| class="IPA wikitable" |- ! English ! oblique ! subject ! locative ! vocative |- | I | [tá] | [tān] |[tȁtʼn̄] |- | you (sg.) | [ní] | [nēn] | [nȉtʼn̄] | [wȍ] (m.), [hȁ] (f.) |- | you (hon.) | [jìnt] | [jìnt] | [jìnt] |- | he | [jı̋] | [jīs] | _ |- | he (hon.) | [ı̋ts] | [ı̋ts] | [ı̋ts] |- | she | [wű] | [wūs] | _ |- | she (hon.) | [ɡēn] | [ɡēn] | [ɡēn] |- | himself/herself | [bá] | [bān] | [bȁtʼn̄] |- | we (excl.) | [nú] | [nūn] | [nȕtʼn̄] |- | we (incl.) | [nı̋] | [nīn] | [nȉtʼn̄] |- | you (pl.) | [jìntȁjkʼn̄] | [jìntȁjkʼn̄] | [jìntȁjkʼn̄] |- | they | [ı̋tsȁjkʼn̄] | [ı̋tsȁjkʼn̄] | [ı̋tsȁjkʼn̄] |} The word {{IPA|[bá]}} goes slightly beyond being a [[reflexive pronoun]]; it can mark any third person that refers to the subject of the sentence, e.g.: :{| |{{IPA|[jȉsī}}||{{IPA|bá}}||{{IPA|dōr}}||{{IPA|ɡȍtùē]}} |- |he.[[subject (grammar)|S]]||own||sheep||sell.he.Fin{{Clarify|date=February 2009}} |} :"he sold his (own) sheep" :{| |{{IPA|[bȍdám}}||{{IPA|hāŋkʼá}}||{{IPA|bājístāɡùʂn̄}}||{{IPA|pāntsʼà}}||{{IPA|ěz]}} |- |road.[[ablative case|{{sm|abl}}]]||go.self||self.be.[[stative|{{sm|stat}}]].[[determiner (linguistics)|{{sm|det}}]].when||leopard-NPMk{{Clarify|date=February 2009}}||big||see.he.Fin{{Clarify|date=February 2009}} |} :"when he was going along the road, he saw a big leopard" The oblique form is basic, and serves as object, possessive, and adverbial. The subject form has three variants: normal (given above), emphatic - used when the subject is particularly prominent in the sentence, especially sentence-initially - and reduced, used as part of a verb phrase. The "locative" term means "to, at, or for one's own place or house", e.g.: :{| |{{IPA|[kȁrtá}}||{{IPA|tȁtʼn̄}}||{{IPA|tā}}||{{IPA|hāŋkʼùē]}} |- |return.I||to.my.house||I||go.I.Fin{{Clarify|date=February 2009}} |} :"I went home" ====Determiners==== The main determiners are "that, the" (masc. {{IPA|[ùʂ]}}, fem. {{IPA|[èn]}}, pl. {{IPA|[ènd]}}) and "this" (masc. {{IPA|[hàʂ]}}, fem. {{IPA|[hàn]}}, pl. {{IPA|[hànd]}}). As suffixes on a verb or an ablative or locative phrase, they indicate a relative clause. E.g.: :{| |{{IPA|[ātsn̄dà]}}||{{IPA|[hàndīs]}}||{{IPA|[hǎrám]}}||{{IPA|[bād]}}||{{IPA|[átsn̄dȁ?]}} |- |person.[[plural|{{sm|pl}}]].NPMk||these.[[object (grammar)|O]]||what.[[ablative case|{{sm|abl}}]]||separate||make.[[future tense|{{sm|fut}}]].Intl{{Clarify|date=February 2009}}? |} :"how can I separate these people?" :{| |{{IPA|[átsín}}||{{IPA|kétn̋}}||{{IPA|jískèn]}} |- |woman||house.[[locative|{{sm|loc}}]]||be.that |} "the woman who is in the house" ===Demonstratives=== The [[demonstrative]]s include {{IPA|[háŋ]}} "here", {{IPA|[ēk]}} "there (nearby)", {{IPA|[jìŋk]}} "there (far away)", {{IPA|[nēɡ]}} "down there", {{IPA|[nèk]}} "up there". Alone, or with the determiner suffixes {{IPA|[ùʂ]}} or {{IPA|[àʂ]}} added, these function as demonstrative pronouns "this person", "that person", etc. With the noun phrase marker {{IPA|[-à]}}, they become demonstrative adjectives. E.g.: :{| |{{IPA|[hàŋ}}||{{IPA|nás}}||{{IPA|dȁdn̄}}||{{IPA|àtāɡùʂn̄]}} |- |here||man||near||reach.[[stative|{{sm|stat}}]].[[determiner (linguistics)|{{sm|det}}]].when |} :"when he came near to the man..." :{| |{{IPA|[njāʔà}}||{{IPA|nēɡà}}||{{IPA|hàndī]}} |- |boy.NPMk||down.there.NPMk||[[determiner (linguistics)|{{sm|det}}]].[[subject (grammar)|S]] |} :"these boys down there" ===Numbers=== The numbers are: {| class="IPA wikitable" |- | 1 | [mātʼ] |- | 2 | [nám] |- | 3 | [káz] |- | 4 | [ód] |- | 5 | [ùtʂ] |- | 6 | [sàpm̄] |- | 7 | [nàpm̄] |- | 8 | [njàrtn̄] |- | 9 | [ìrstn̄] |- | 10 | [ta̋m] |- | 100 | [bǎl] |- | 1000 | [wňm] |} 20, 30, etc. are formed by adding {{IPA|[tàm]}} "ten" (with tone change) to the unit. In compound numbers, {{IPA|[-á]}} is added to each 'figure, thus: :13 {{IPA|[ta̋má kázá]}} :236 {{IPA|[nám bǎlá kāztàmá sàpm̄á]}} When a [[cardinal number]] functions as an adjective, the suffix {{IPA|[-ās]}} can be added ''(e.g.'' {{IPA|[njāʔà kázās]}} "three children"). [[Ordinal number]]s are formed by suffixing {{IPA|[-nás]}} to the cardinal, e.g.: {{IPA|[ódnás]}} "fourth". ===Adjectives=== Adjectives are sometimes intensified by changing the tone to top; e.g. {{IPA|[ěz]}} "big" → {{IPA|[e̋z]}} "very big". ===Verbs=== Verbs with monosyllabic roots can have three different forms of their active stems: the singular imperative, which is just the root; the past stem, usually identical to the root but sometimes formed by adding ''-k'' (with changes to the preceding consonant); and the future stem, usually identical to the root but sometimes formed by changing the tone from mid 3 to high 4 or from bottom 1 to top 5. Some have causative (formed by adding {{IPA|[-ās]}} or {{IPA|[-̏s]}}, and changing mid tone to high) and passive (formed by adding {{IPA|[-n̄]}}, {{IPA|[-t]}}, or {{IPA|[-̏k]}} to the causative) forms. Verbal nouns are formed from the stem, sometimes with tone change or addition or {{IPA|[-t]}}. Verbs with polysyllabic roots have at least two forms, one with an intransitive or passive meaning and one with a transitive or causative meaning; the former ends in {{IPA|[-n̄]}}, the latter in {{IPA|[-ās]}}. A passive may be formed by ending in {{IPA|[-āsn̄]}}. Verbal nouns are formed by taking the bare stem without {{IPA|[-n̄]}} or {{IPA|[-ās]}}. Compound verbs are formed with {{IPA|[màk]}} "say" or {{IPA|[màs]}} "cause to say", a formation common among Ethiopian languages. The primary tenses are simple past (formed from the past stem), future (future stem plus {{IPA|[-n̄s-]}}), present perfect (from present participle stem); negative (future stem plus {{IPA|[-árɡ-]}}.) E.g.: {{IPA|[hām]}} → {{IPA|[hāŋkʼùē]}} "he went"; {{IPA|[hámsm̄sùē]}} "he will go"; {{IPA|[hāŋkʼńsùē]}} "he has gone". There are four corresponding participles: past (formed from the past stem), present perfect (formed from the past stem with the suffix {{IPA|[-ńs-]}}, {{IPA|[-ńɡ]}}, or {{IPA|[-áŋkʼ-]}}), imperfect (formed from the future stem with the stative suffix {{IPA|[-āɡ-]}}), and negative (formed from the future stem with the negative suffix {{IPA|[-árɡ-]}} or {{IPA|[-ù-]}} or a person/number marker.) The order of affixes is: root-(tense)-(negative)-(foc. pn.)-person/number-marker. ==Orthography and literature== [[File:Bench New Testament, ISBN 9966-40-063-X.jpg|thumb|Bench New Testament, {{ISBN|9966-40-063-X}}]] A Latin-based orthography was adopted in 2008. Previously, the [[New Testament]] had been published in the Bench language using an orthography based on the [[Ge'ez script|Ethiopian syllabary]]. Tones were not indicated. Retroflex consonants were indicated by such techniques as using extra symbols from the syllabary (the "''nigus'' s") and forming new symbols (the addition of an extra arm on the left side for "t"). == Notes == {{Reflist}} == References == * Breeze, Mary J. 1986. "Personal pronouns in Gimira (Benchnon)." In Ursula Wiesemann (ed.), ''Pronominal systems'', 47-69. Tübingen: Gunter Narr. * Breeze, Mary J. 1988. "Phonological features of Gimira and Dizi." In Marianne Bechhaus-Gerst and Fritz Serzisko (eds.), ''Cushitic - Omotic: papers from the International Symposium on Cushitic and Omotic languages, Cologne, January 6–9, 1986'', 473-487. Hamburg: Helmut Buske Verlag. * Breeze, Mary J. 1990. "A Sketch of the Phonology and Grammar of Gimira (Benchnon)". In [[Richard J. Hayward]] (ed.), ''Omotic Language Studies'', 1-67. London: School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London. * Rapold, Christian. 2006. ''Towards a grammar of Benchnon.'' PhD thesis, University of Leiden. * Wedekind, Klaus. 1983. "A six-tone language in Ethiopia: Tonal analysis of Benč non (Gimira)." ''Journal of Ethiopian Studies'' 16: 129-56. * Wedekind, Klaus. 1985a. "Why Bench’ (Ethiopia) has five level tones today." In Ursula Pieper and Gerhard Stickel (eds.), ''Studia linguistica diachronica et synchronica'', 881-901. Berlin: Mouton. * Wedekind, Klaus. 1985b. "Thoughts when drawing a map of tone languages." ''Afrikanistische Arbeitspapiere'' 1: 105-24. *Wedekind, Klaus. 1990. "Gimo-Jan or Ben-Yem-Om: Benč - Yemsa phonemes, tones, and words." In Richard J. Hayward (ed.), ''Omotic language studies'' p. 68-184. London: School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London. ==External links== * Wedekind, Klaus. 1983. [https://web.archive.org/web/20110719053906/http://www.kwedekind.de///Eingang1///PdfFiles/1983_ASixToneLanguage.pdf A Six-Tone Language in Ethiopia] * Wedekind, Klaus. 1985a. http://www.kwedekind.de///Eingang1///PdfFiles/1985_WhyBenchHasFiveLevelTonesToday.pdf * Wedekind, Klaus. 1985a. http://www.kwedekind.de///Eingang1///PdfFiles/1985_Thoughts_when_Drawing_a_Map_of_Tone_Languages.pdf * [[World Atlas of Language Structures]] information: http://wals.info/languoid/lect/wals_code_gim * [http://www.bench-web.com Website maintained by the Bench community, on culture and language, in the Bench language] {{Languages of Ethiopia}} {{Omotic languages}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bench Language}} [[Category:Languages of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Ta-Ne-Omotic languages]] [[Category:Tonal languages]] [[Category:Whistled languages]]

{{Infobox orchestra | name = British Paraorchestra | type = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | short_name = | image = | caption = | alt = | former_name = | founded = {{Start date|2011}} | disbanded = <!-- {{End date|YYYY}} --> | later_name = | location = [[Bristol]], England | concert_hall = [[At-Bristol]] | principal_conductor = [[Charles Hazlewood]] | music_director = | website = {{URL|paraorchestra.com}} }}
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} The '''British Paraorchestra''', based in Bristol, is an [[orchestra]] consisting entirely of musicians with [[disability|disabilities]]{{emdash}}the first ever orchestra of its kind in the United Kingdom.<ref name=telegraph-paraorchestra/> The Paraorchestra was formed by conductor [[Charles Hazlewood]] in 2011 as a project to create a platform for the top disabled musicians, with the hope that its success would lead to better [[Community integration|integration]] of the disabled into music and [[performing arts]]. The orchestra performed its first live show at [[Glastonbury Abbey]] in July 2012 (which was also the subject of a [[Channel 4]] documentary), and received international attention when it played alongside [[Coldplay]] during the [[2012 Summer Paralympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] of the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] in [[London]] in September 2012.
==History==
===Origins=== Charles Hazlewood was inspired by his youngest daughter Eliza to form the Paraorchestra; Eliza has [[cerebral palsy]], but Hazlewood believed that she was still an "outstanding" singer. Being the father of a child with a disability, he realized that throughout his career as an orchestral conductor, he had seen few disabled performers as members of orchestras. Hazlewood felt that since music is "universal", an orchestra should represent all members of a community{{emdash}}comparing this ordeal to the time when only men performed in orchestras. He felt that an orchestra consisting only of disabled performers could spread awareness of this issue and help achieve greater [[Community integration|integration]] for the disabled in music and the performing arts.<ref name=nat-para/><ref name=guardian-paraorchestra>{{cite news|title=Coldplay join the paraorchestra of disabled musicians for closing ceremony|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/sep/01/orchestra-disabled-people-play-paralympics?newsfeed=true|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=11 September 2012|location=London|first=Maggie|last=Brown|date=1 September 2012}}</ref>
===Formation=== Hazlewood officially announced the formation of the British Paraorchestra in July 2011 at a [[TED (conference)|TED conference]] in [[Edinburgh]].<ref name=nat-para/> He did not intend the Paraorchestra to be a [[Music therapy|therapeutic]] or "warm and fuzzy" project, but rather a platform to showcase disabled musicians with [[virtuoso|virtuosic]] qualities. When holding auditions, he aimed to find musicians who were "at the top of their game, technically, and with a spirit behind the virtuosity." The orchestra's first 17 members come from a variety of backgrounds and use a variety of instruments, including conventional instruments and electronic devices such as [[tablet computer]]s and other assistive technology developed by [[Rolf Gehlhaar]], Professor in Experimental Music at Coventry University and the technical director of the orchestra.<ref name=guardian-paraorchestra/> After failing to partner with the [[BBC]], Hazlewood successfully commissioned British broadcaster [[Channel 4]] to produce a documentary following the formation of the Paraorchestra and its first performance, which aired on 9 September 2012. He felt airing its documentary on Channel 4 was a "no-brainer", as it was also the official broadcaster of the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]].<ref name=guardian-paraorchestra/>
The Paraorchestra made its first public appearance on 1 July 2012 during Hazlewood's music festival "Orchestra in a Field" at [[Glastonbury Abbey]]; the performance included its versions of "[[Greensleeves]]" and [[Maurice Ravel]]'s ''[[Boléro]]''.<ref name=guardian-paraorchestra/> The orchestra's style incorporates a large amount of [[Musical improvisation|improvisation]], intended to allow the orchestra to feel a sense of "collective ownership" of their performances.<ref name=nat-para>{{cite web|last=Champ|first=Gemma|title=The British Paraorchestra hit the right notes|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/on-stage/the-british-paraorchestra-hit-the-right-notes|publisher=The National|accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref>
===Involvement with the Paralympics=== In 2012, Hazlewood campaigned for the Paraorchestra to be included in the ceremonies of the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] in London. He felt that their inclusion in this international event would be a unique opportunity for the Paraorchestra and that it could also raise awareness of his cause.<ref name=guardian-paraorchestra/> The Paraorchestra were ultimately incorporated into the [[2012 Summer Paralympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] of the Games, where it performed alongside British rock band [[Coldplay]] (accompanying them in a performance of "[[Strawberry Swing]]"), and played the [[Paralympic anthem]].<ref name=guardian-paraorchestra/> The Paraorchestra planned to use the exposure it gained through its role at the Paralympics to add more performers, make [[studio recording]]s, and tour across Europe.<ref name=guardian-paraorchestra/>
On 3 December 2012, coinciding with the [[United Nations]]' [[United Nations' International Day of Persons with Disabilities|International Day of Persons with Disabilities]], the British Paraorchestra released a cover of "[[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper song)|True Colors]]" as a [[charity single]], in a campaign to be [[List of UK Singles Chart Christmas number ones|Christmas number one]]. Accompanied by the [[Kaos Signing Choir for Deaf and Hearing Children]] and notable Britiah paralympians, the single was released to support the [[British Paralympic Association]] in preparation for the [[2014 Winter Paralympics]], along with the Paraorchestra and Kaos Signing Choir themselves.<ref name=ipc-truecolors>{{cite web|title=British Paraorchestra heads for No. 1 this Christmas|url=http://www.paralympic.org/news/british-paraorchestra-heads-no-1-christmas|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|accessdate=8 December 2012}}</ref> The Paraorchestra was awarded a [[Big Society Award]] in September 2013.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=British Paraorchestra win Prime Minister's Big Society Award |url=http://www.classicfm.com/music-news/latest-news/british-paraorchestra-big-society-award/ |newspaper=Classic FM |location= |date=26 September 2013 |access-date=29 January 2015 }}</ref>
== Members == The Paraorchestra began with 17 members, but plans to add more in the near future.<ref name=guardian-paraorchestra/> Its members currently include [[Nicholas McCarthy (pianist)|Nicholas McCarthy]], a one-handed pianist who graduated from the [[Royal College of Music]] in 2012, [[Clarence Adoo]], a former jazz trumpet player who was paralysed below the shoulders after a car accident (and now plays an instrument known as "Headspace", which is controlled by breath and head motions, developed for him by [[Rolf Gehlhaar]]), [[Gemma Lunt]], a [[viola]] player who uses a [[wheelchair]] and [[Lyn Levett]], who uses a [[Macintosh]] to play what Hazlewood feels is "dizzyingly creative" [[electronic music]].<ref name=telegraph-paraorchestra>{{cite news|title=One-handed pianist Nicholas McCarthy graduates from Royal College of Music|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/9503659/One-handed-pianist-Nicholas-McCarthy-graduates-from-Royal-College-of-Music.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=10 September 2012|location=London|first=Donna|last=Bowater|date=28 August 2012}}</ref> Blind members of the Paraorchestra include Pianist and violinist [[Abi Baker]], [[James Risdon]] on [[Recorder (musical instrument)|recorder]], [[Matthew Wadsworth]] on the [[lute]], violist [[Takashi Kikuchi]], and multi-instrumentalists [[Baluji Shrivastav]] and [[Ziad Sinno]].<ref name=nat-para/> The Paraorchestra also recently added 15-year-old [[deafness|deaf]] [[viola]] player Tilly Chester to its lineup. Hazlewood had encountered her playing with the [[National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain|National Youth Orchestra]]{{emdash}}of which she is also a member.<ref name=tilly-parabbc>{{cite news|title=Worcester teenager Tilly Chester selected for Paraorchestra|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hereford-worcester-19535754|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=10 September 2012}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Disability in the arts]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website}} * [http://www.ted.com/talks/the_debut_of_the_british_paraorchestra The debut of the British Paraorchestra] at [[TEDx|TEDxBrussels]] in 2011

'''Carnography''' (also '''carno'''<ref name="Time"/>) refers to excessive or extended scenes of [[wikt:carnage|carnage]], [[violence]], and [[graphic violence|gore]] in media such as [[film]], [[literature]], and [[image]]s.<ref name="Wordspy">{{cite web | title = Word Spy — carnography | url = http://www.wordspy.com/words/carnography.asp | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | publisher = Wordspy | quote = Writings, films, images, or other materials that contain scenes of carnage or other types of violence. [Blend of carnage and pornography.] Also: carno}}</ref><ref name="LaRocque">{{cite news | last = LaRocque | first = Paula | title = Language follows society: we can trace our changes by the words we use | url = http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-23088548_ITM | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | date = 2003-04-01 | publisher = [[The Quill (Bowdoin)|The Quill]] | quote = A blend of carnage and pornography gives us carnography, which refers to extended scenes of violence. The word has been used to describe, for example, the long and graphic battle scenes in ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'' and ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]''."}}</ref> The term ''carnography''—a [[portmanteau]] of the words ''carnage'' and ''pornography''<ref name="LaRocque"/>—was used as early as 1972 in [[Time magazine|''Time'' magazine]]'s review of [[David Morrell]]'s book ''[[First Blood (novel)|First Blood]]'', upon which the [[Rambo (film series)|Rambo]] film series is based.<ref name="Winter">{{cite book | last = Winter | first = Douglas E. | title = Faces of fear: encounters with the creators of modern horror | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rC7YA9JYSMMC&q=carnography&dq=carnography&pgis=1 | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | year = 1985 | publisher = Berkley Books | isbn = 0-425-07670-9 | page = 82 | quote = When ''First Blood'' was published in 1972, ''Time'' devoted its lead book review to accusing Morrell of inventing a new form of fiction – "carnography," the violent equivalent of pornography.}}</ref> ''Rambo'' was later called "carnography" as well.<ref name="Rahner">{{cite news |last=Rahner |first=Mark |title=Rambo's back; body parts fly |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/movies/2004143688_rambo25.html |accessdate=2009-04-15 |date=2008-01-25 |publisher=[[Seattle Times]] |quote=Guts fly, limbs get blown off, a throat is torn out, women are raped, children are killed, scores of people are cut to ribbons with machine-gun fire, or blown up — a book I have describes Rambo as "carnography," and this may be the hardest-core mainstream carnography to date. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418193314/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/movies/2004143688_rambo25.html |archivedate=2009-04-18 |df= }}</ref>
The term refers to an obsession with the [[human body]] that "suggests a connection between [[horror fiction|horror]] and [[pornography]]", often relating to hardcore [[horror film]]s. Carnography is considered [[taboo]] and a disreputable genre.<ref name="Pinedo">{{cite book | last = Pinedo | first = Isabel Cristina | title = Recreational terror: women and the pleasures of horror film viewing | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zk_mtptGx8kC&pg=PA60&dq=carnography#PPA61,M1 | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | date = 1997 | publisher = SUNY Press | isbn = 0-7914-3441-9 | page = 61 | quote = The link between hard-core pornography and hard-core horror or the gore film is captured in the term "carnography" (Gehr 1990, 58), which uses the carnality of both genres as a bridge.}}</ref> It has been described as "nastily impure work",<ref name="Harvey">{{cite book | last = Harvey | first = Karen | title = Reading sex in the eighteenth century | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ZmZ6JyOXW0gC&pg=PA21&dq=carnography | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | year = 2004 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 0-521-82235-1 | page = 21 | quote = ... Alan Bold's distinction between 'good erotica' and 'carnography' (the latter meaning 'nastily impure work' written by 'male chauvinists' and imbued with 'the sense of a desire to masticate flesh')...}}</ref> "splatter-obsessed hard core horror",<ref name="Browning">{{cite book | last = Browning | first = Mark | title = David Cronenberg: author or film-maker? | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=prEUHH2jcWAC&pg=PA58&dq=carnography#PPA58,M1 | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | year = 2007 | publisher = Intellect Books | isbn = 1-84150-173-5 | page = 58 | quote = Ian Conrich underlines the 'relationship between the opened bodies of pornography and splatter-obsessed hard core horror' that Richard Gehr calls 'carnography'...}}</ref> and "watching flesh fly".<ref name="Time">{{cite news | last = Skow | first = John | title = Carnography | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,903556,00.html | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | date = 1972-05-29 | publisher = [[Time magazine]] | quote = I am sick of carnography, of sitting safe and watching meat fly. On the screen or on the page. But don't Moby-Dick and Hamlet also end bloodily? And isn't the reader/viewer always a voyeur?}}</ref><ref name="Winter"/> Carnographic horror films have a "superfluous plot" in which characters are "initiated, only to be discarded", and the gore seems to be the only reason the film exists.<ref name="Badley">{{cite book | last = Bradley | first = Linda | title = Film, horror, and the body fantastic | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PD1CZfa5wicC&pg=PA6&dq=carnography#PPA7,M1 | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | year = 1995 | publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group | isbn = 0-313-27523-8 | page = 7}}</ref> Pornography and carnography share the feature of close, intimate physical contact, whether it be to caress or to attack.<ref name="Burtchaell">{{cite book | last = Burtchaell | first = James Tunstead | title = Philemon's problem: a theology of grace | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=WjKQTFFbHiUC&pg=PA182&dq=carnography&lr=#PPA182,M1 | accessdate = 2009-04-15 | year = 1998 | publisher = Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing | isbn = 0-8028-4549-5 | page = 182 | quote = One obvious shared feature [between pornography and carnography] is that both passions involve physical contact...}}</ref>

'''Catherine Henrietta Elliot Fulton''' (née '''Valpy''', 19 December 1829 – 6 May 1919) was a [[New Zealand]] diarist, community leader, philanthropist, social reformer and [[suffragette]].
==Early life== Fulton was one of six children born to [[William Henry Valpy]] and Caroline Valpy (née Jeffreys). She was born in [[Cheltenham]], [[Gloucestershire]] or in [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], [[Berkshire]], England on 19 December 1829.<ref name="DNZB Catherine Fulton">{{DNZB|Entwisle|Rosemary|1f19|Fulton, Catherine Henrietta Elliot|29 July 2012}}</ref> She was educated in England and arrived in New Zealand on the ''Ajax'' in January 1849.<ref name="DNZB Catherine Fulton" />
==Public life== Fulton married [[James Fulton (New Zealand politician)|James Fulton]] in 1852 and moved to his farm "Ravenscliffe" on the [[Taieri Plains]], Otago. Together they had eight children,<ref name="DNZB Catherine Fulton" /> several of whom became notable in their own right (most famously the engineer [[James Edward Fulton]]).
Fulton was the Dominion President of the [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union|Women's Christian Temperance Union]] from 1889 to 1892. She helped found the Dunedin branch in May 1885 and was its first President. Along with her sisters [[Ellen Penelope Jeffreys|Ellen]] and [[Arabella Valpy|Arabella]], she established the Band of Hope Coffee Rooms. She was a strong advocate for women's suffrage and included in her diaries her frustration with politicians who opposed it.<ref name="DNZB Catherine Fulton" />
In 1879, James Fulton was elected to the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], and in 1889 was appointed to the [[New Zealand Legislative Council|Legislative Council]]. Fulton later attended the council sessions daily, along with the wives of other parliamentarians, to follow the passage of the Women's Suffrage bill through the House. When the Bill was passed in 1893, she drove her women neighbours to the polling booths so they could vote.<ref>{{Cite book |title = The Book of New Zealand Women|editor-last = Macdonald |editor-first = Charlotte |publisher = Bridget Williams Books| year = 1991 |isbn = 0908912048 |location = Wellington, New Zealand |pages = 702–704}}</ref>
After her husband died in 1891, she continued to run the farm alone.<ref name="DNZB Catherine Fulton" /> Aged 90, she died on 6 May 1919 and was survived by three sons and three daughters.<ref name="ES obit">{{cite news |title=Obituary |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=ESD19190507.2.23 |accessdate=26 October 2015 |work=[[Evening Star (Dunedin)|Evening Star]] |issue=17037 |date=7 May 1919 |page=3}}</ref>

{{Infobox prepared food | name = Colcannon | image = Colcannon.JPG | image_size = 250px | caption = A pot of freshly made colcannon | alternate_name = | country = [[Ireland]] | region = | creator = | course = | type = | served = | main_ingredient = [[Mashed potato]]es, [[kale]] or [[cabbage]] | variations = | calories = | other = }} [[File:Colcannon recipe on bag of potatoes (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Colcannon recipe on a bag of potatoes]] '''Colcannon''' ({{Irish place name|cál ceannann|white-headed cabbage}}) is a traditional [[Ireland|Irish]] dish of [[mashed potato]]es with [[kale]] or [[cabbage]]. ==Description== Colcannon is traditionally made from mashed potatoes and kale (or cabbage), with [[milk]] (or [[cream]]), [[butter]] (or [[vegetable oil]]), [[salt]] and [[Black pepper|pepper]] added. It can contain other ingredients such as [[scallion]]s (spring onions), [[leek]]s, [[Laver (seaweed)|laver]], [[onion]]s and [[chive]]s. There are many regional variations of this dish.[http://www.bordbia.ie/aboutfood/recipes/potatoes/pages/colcannan.aspx Recipe from An Bord Bia (Irish food board)] It is often eaten with boiled [[ham]] or [[Back bacon|Irish bacon]]. At one time it was a cheap, year-round staple food,{{cite book|last=Irwin |first=Florence |title=The Cookin' Woman: Irish Country Recipes |publisher=Blackstaff |year=1986 |isbn=0-85640-373-3}} though nowadays it is usually eaten in autumn/winter, when kale comes into season.[http://www.redrussiankale.co.uk/11.html Molyneux Kale] An Irish [[Halloween]] tradition is to serve colcannon with a ring and a thimble hidden in the dish. Prizes of small coins such as threepenny or sixpenny bits were also concealed inside the dish.{{cite book | title=Irish Traditional Cooking | publisher=Gill and Macmillan | author=Allen, Darina | year=2012| location=Dublin | page=152 | isbn=9780717154364}} ==Etymology== The origin of the word is unclear. The first syllable 'col' is likely derived from the Irish 'cál' meaning cabbage. The second syllable may derive from 'ceann-fhionn' meaning a white head (i.e. 'a white head of cabbage') - this use is also found in the Irish name for a coot, a white headed bird known as 'cearc cheannan', or 'white-head hen'. The phrase may also be borrowed from the Welsh name for a leek soup known as [[cawl cennin]], literally "broth (of) leeks."{{cite book|last=Evans |first=H. Meurig |title=Y Geiriadur Mawr |publisher=Gwasg Gomer |year=1980}} ==Song== The song "Colcannon", also called "The Skillet Pot", is a traditional Irish song that has been recorded by numerous artists, including [[Mary Black]]."The Black Family" CD, 1986, Dara Records, DARA CD 023 It begins:
Did you ever eat Colcannon, made from lovely pickled cream? With the greens and scallions mingled like a picture in a dream. Did you ever make a hole on top to hold the melting flake Of the creamy, flavoured butter that your mother used to make?
The chorus:
Yes you did, so you did, so did he and so did I. And the more I think about it sure the nearer I'm to cry. Oh, wasn't it the happy days when troubles we had not, And our mothers made Colcannon in the little skillet pot.
==See also== {{portal|Food}} * [[List of cabbage dishes]] * [[List of Irish dishes]] * [[List of potato dishes]] * [[Champ (food)|Champ]], Irish mashed potato dish *[[bubble and squeak]], English potato dish *[[clapshot]] and [[rumbledethumps]], Scottish dishes *[[stamppot]], Dutch potato dish ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary|Colcannon}} {{Irish cuisine}} {{Potato dishes}} [[Category:Irish cuisine]] [[Category:Potato dishes]] [[Category:Halloween food]] [[Category:Irish words and phrases]] [[Category:Brassica oleracea dishes]] [[Category:Cabbage dishes]] [[Category:Vegetarian cuisine]] [[Category:National dishes]]

'''FADFED''' is a [[methodology]] for [[Survey research|public opinion research]] that combines elements of quantitative and qualitative approaches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.placesofdiversity.org/index.php/good-examples/63-fadfed-let-it-out|title=Fadfed ''Let it Out"'|author=LoT|work=placesofdiversity.org}}</ref> Developed in [[Amman, Jordan]], FADFED has been used in the Middle East, Europe, and the United States. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/initiative-takes-political-discussions-street |title=Initiative takes political discussions to the street |work=jordantimes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222075627/http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/initiative-takes-political-discussions-street |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://designlab360.org/jordan-html/email.html|title=Youth, Gender and Employability in the Mena Region|work=designlab360.org}}</ref>
FADFED, translated "Speak it Out" or "Let it Out" in [[Arabic]], was invented by Dr. Sami Hourani and introduced by the Leaders of Tomorrow organization in Amman in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fadfed.org/#about|title=FADFED Initiative مبادرة فضفض|work=FADFED Initiative مبادرة فضفض}}</ref> FADFED involves placing white sheets of paper in public spaces and inviting individuals to write on these sheets of paper their responses to a given question prompt or prompts. Researchers using FADFED categorize respondents by [[demographics]] as suits their research purposes; for instance, by age or gender. A researcher does so by establishing a color coding of markers used at a particular event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://irckhf.org/en/organization/fadfed|title=FadFed|work=irckhf.org}}</ref> Red markers might be given to women, or green markers to those over 50 years old, as an example. FADFED generates both written and oral discussion and debate on subject topics, and thus raises awareness of often controversial or politically sensitive issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://informationactivism.org/en/fadfed-surveying-public-opinion|title=Fadfed: Surveying public opinion|work=10 Tactics Remixed}}</ref> FADFED may be accompanied by surveys that help to establish demographic data for a given opinion-gathering event.
FADFED is primarily qualitative in nature, but because it attracts many responses quickly (often hundreds in one or two hours) the data produced can be assessed quantitatively as well. In some ways, FADFED resembles [[focus group]] research in that it produces open-ended responses from many people in a short amount of time. However, because all FADFED responses are given independently, there is no danger that one voice or opinion could dominate a group discussion, as there can be in focus group research. FADFED gives equal voice to all who choose to respond.<ref>{{Cite web|title = “فض فض”: دعوة للتعبير بحرية على ألواح بيضاء في الشوارع|url = http://islahnews.net/140563.html|website = islahnews.net}}</ref>
